verses.text: Wisdom hath built her house, she hath hewn out her seven pillars:
She hath killed her beasts; she hath mingled her wine; she hath also furnished her table.
She hath sent forth her maidens: she crieth upon the highest places of the city,
Whoever \add is\add* simple, let him turn in hither: \add as for\add* him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him,
Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine \add which\add* I have mingled.
Forsake the foolish, and live; and go in the way of understanding.
He that reproveth a scorner, getteth to himself shame: and he that rebuketh a wicked \add man getteth\add* himself a blot.
Reprove not a scorner, lest he shall hate thee: rebuke a wise man, and he will love thee.
Give \add instruction\add* to a wise \add man\add* , and he will be yet wiser: teach a just \add man\add* , and he will increase in learning.
The fear of the LORD \add is\add* the beginning of wisdom: and the knowledge of the holy \add is\add* understanding.
For by me thy days shall be multiplied, and the years of thy life shall be increased.
If thou art wise, thou shalt be wise for thyself: but \add if\add* thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear \add it\add* .
A foolish woman \add is\add* clamorous: \add she is\add* simple, and knoweth nothing.
For she sitteth at the door of her house, on a seat in the high places of the city,
To call passengers who go right on their ways:
Whoever \add is\add* simple, let him turn in hither: and \add as for\add* him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him,
Stolen waters are sweet, and bread \add eaten\add* in secret is pleasant.
But he knoweth not that the dead \add are\add* there; \add and that\add* her guests \add are\add* in the depths of hell.
